title: Is this grammatically correct, “She doesn’t want to be videoed, that’s why she didn’t look at the camera”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here, the sentence uses wrong punctuation mark, comma. Several comma (,) usages are to separate idea(s) and finish the dependent sentence (in beginning). Comma can also be used before conjunction. Here are some examples: There are apples, oranges and bananasWhen he is reading, I am cookingShe loves… , but she hates…For more comma usages: 13 Rules For Using Commas Without Looking Like An Idiot The sentence you ask above should not use comma because there is no conjunction after comma. If you want to use comma, your sentence should be: “She doesn't want to be videoed, so that's why she didn't look at the camera.”“She doesn't want to be videoed, and that's why she didn't look at the camera.” To combine both of them without using conjunction, you need to use semicolon (;), which one of its functions is to join the independent clauses which are related to/contrast to one another. Then, your sentence will be: “She doesn't want to be videoed; that's why she didn't look at the camera.”** If you want to use period, your sentence will consist of two independent clauses: “She doesn't want to be videoed. That's why she didn't look at the camera.”

It isn’t correct in formal writing, because you have two principle clauses (“She doesn’t want to be videoed” and “That’s why she didn’t look at the camera.”) You can have two or more clauses in a sentence, but in formal writing they must be joined by a co-ordinate conjunction that usually shows the relationship between the ideas in the clauses. She doesn’t want to be videoed and that’s why she didn’t look at the camera. She doesn’t want to be videoed, so she didn’t look at the camera. She doesn’t want to be videoed, yet she looked at the camera. She doesn’t want to be videoed, but she looked at the camera. You cannot use commas to join clauses; commas separate things to make the meaning clear. The exception would be a list of principle clauses like this: John did his homework, Mary played video games, and the twins cleaned the house. Here the list structure supersedes the rule about joining clauses.

Is this grammatically correct, “She doesn’t want to be videoed, that’s why she didn’t look at the camera”? This sentence is perfectly correct. Some others have referred to the fact that the tenses don't agree. “She doesn't want to be videoed” Present simple, negative, passive. Therefore: She doesnt want to be videoed in general. She didn't want to be videoed in the past and she won't want to be videoed in the future. “That” in this instance is a subordinating conjunction preceded by a comma “She didn’t look at the camera” past simple negative. She didn't look at the camera in one occasion in the past.

The verb tenses are okay. You may be in the process of doing something and during that process, she doesn’t want to be filmed (a better word) so a few minute ago when someone tried to take a video, she didn’t look at the camera. In the written form, you cannot join two sentences with a comma. As others have explained: add a conjuction ex. She doesn’t want to be recorded/filmed and that’s why she didn’t look at the camera.make two sentences with a period ex. She doesn’t want to be filmed. That’s why she didn’t look at the camers.join two sentences (that are closely related) with a semi-colon ex. She doesn’t want to be filmed; that’s why she didn’t look at the camera.A2A

‘videoed’ is a somewhat unusual verb - I would say ‘photographed’ or ‘filmed’ instead. Grammatically, the sentence is about correct, but it would be more correct to use a semi-colon to divide the clauses, or else use a connecting word (a conjunction) such as ‘which’ or ‘therefore’. ‘She doesn’t want to be filmed, which is why she didn’t look at the camera.’ Your verb in the first clause is present tense, while the verb in the second phrase is past tense - I would let that go, since ‘she doesn’t want to be filmed’ can easily mean that she didn’t want to be filmed, she doesn’t want to be filmed now, and she doesn’t ever want to be filmed. But it might be slightly better to have the verbs in each clause in the same tense - ‘She doesn’t want to be filmed, therefore she isn’t looking at the camera.’ or ‘She didn’t want to be filmed, so she didn’t look at the camera.’

[thanks for A2A] Without the A2A I probably wouldn’t have replied — you’ve gotten some helpful responses already. “Video” as a verb is awkward in the past tense, even more so as a gerund — “He enjoys videoing his daughter’s performances.” Ick. In the past tense “filmed” is better. Purists might then say Wait, there’s no film! OK, appease them with “she doesn’t want to be recorded.” The answers are also right about joining two clauses. The way you’ve put it probably works in informal speech, but not in writing. Use two sentences, or a semicolon, or a conjunction (“…doesn’t want to be filmed, so [or ‘and’] that’s why…” (Jean Reynolds is almost exactly right with “You can do this [i.e. semicolon] any time!” The two clauses have to be somehow related to each other.)

A2A response. The first part of the sentence has a present tense verb. I believe this portion describes the general mindset of the person, both in the past and present. That’s an interpretation, not a grammatical thing. The second part has a past tense verb because the incident occurred in the past. I would leave the sentence as it is. My interpretation is that the woman has always had a general dislike about being the subject of video. This displeasure is why she did not look at the camera when the incident took place in the past. Use a semicolon in place of the comma.

“She doesn’t want to be videoed, that’s why she didn’t look at the camera” indicates to me that she did not want to be videoed at that time and she still does not want to be videoed. If that is the intended context of the clause, the sentence is grammatically correct. If this was a one-time event, the verb tenses should agree. In that case it could be either “She doesn’t want to be videoed, that’s why she doesn’t look at the camera” or “She didn’t want to be videoed, that’s why she didn’t look at the camera”.

Is this grammatically correct, “She doesn’t want to be videoed, that’s why she didn’t look at the camera”? No. It’s a run-on sentence. It should read “She doesn’t want to be videoed. That’s why she didn’t look at the camera.”

Forget all the gobbledygook about clauses. Sentences end with periods. They don’t end with commas. So: She doesn’t want to be videoed. That’s why she didn’t look at the camera. If you want to impress someone, change the period to a semicolon and lower-case the next word. You can do this any time! She doesn’t want to be videoed; that’s why she didn’t look at the camera.

100% correct. The girl did not want and still does not want to be videoed. Hence doesn’t (present tense) for the continual not wanting to be videoed. Hence didn’t (past tense) representing the one time when she indicated this.

Video is a relatively new verb and doesn’t appear in many dictionaries. It is valid and is used correctly here. That can rarely be usd as a conjunction. This is not a place for that. Substitute it’s here and you’ll see the point. There are clearly two sentences. Start the second with either that’s or it’s. While people will speak that way, written English should be shown correctly.
It’s acceptable grammar (and socially normal behavior to set and demand conformance to one's preferences for personal and public boundaries).
I would have made it simpler. “She doesn't want to be videoed and that is why she didn't look at the camera.”’ Thanks for the question.
